subject: probability
title: Delta Method: Asymptotic Distribution of g(X̄)
statementHtml: Let $g(x) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{x}}$ and $X_1, X_2, ..., X_n$ be i.i.d. random variables with mean $\mu$. Find the asymptotic distribution of $g(\bar{X}_n)$.",
hints: Hint: Use the delta method to find the asymptotic distribution.
Think about the Taylor series expansion.
solutionHtml:
To apply the delta method, we need to find the first two derivatives of $g(x)$. We have:

  • $g'(x) = -\frac{1}{2x^{3/2}}$
  • $g''(x) = \frac{3}{4x^{5/2}}$

Now, we can use the delta method:

  • We have $\sqrt{n}(\bar{X}_n - \mu) \rightarrow N(0, 1)$.
  • The first derivative of $g(x)$ at $x = \mu$ is $g'(\mu) = -\frac{1}{2\sqrt{\mu}}$.
  • We can plug in these values into the delta method formula:
\[ \sqrt{n}(g(\bar{X}_n) - g(\mu)) \rightarrow N(0, (g'(\mu))^2 \cdot 1) = N(0, \frac{1}{4\mu}) \] },
problemHtml:
Suppose we have a random sample of $n$ observations from a normal distribution with mean $\mu$ and variance $\sigma^2$. Find the asymptotic distribution of the sample standard deviation.

intuition: The delta method helps us find the asymptotic distribution of a function by using the first two derivatives and the central limit theorem.
realWorldApplications: In machine learning, this method can be used to find the asymptotic distribution of various statistics, such as the sample mean or standard deviation.

title: Delta Method: Asymptotic Distribution of g(X̄)
contentHtml: The Delta method is a powerful tool in probability theory that allows us to find the asymptotic distribution of a function g(X̄) when X̄ is normally distributed.

problem.statementHtml: Find the asymptotic distribution of g(X̄) when X̄ is normally distributed.
problem.solutionHtml:
Solution steps:

  • We need to find the first two moments of g(X̄).
  • The mean is \(\mathbb{E}[g(X̄)] = 0\).
  • The variance is \(\text{Var}[g(X̄)] = \frac{1}{n}\).
  • Now we can apply the Delta method.
problem.answerShort: Normal distribution with mean 0 and variance \(\frac{1}{n}\)

workedExample.problemHtml: Suppose we have a sample of n = 10 observations from a normal distribution with mean \(\mu\) and variance \(\sigma^2\). Find the asymptotic distribution of g(X̄) = \(\frac{1}{\sqrt{10}} \sum_{i=1}^{10} x_i\).

steps.description: Find the first two moments of g(X̄)
steps.explanation: The mean is zero because we're averaging out the noise
The variance is \(\frac{1}{n}\) because we're taking a sample average
We standardize g(X̄) by subtracting its mean and dividing by its standard deviation

workedExample.finalAnswer: Normal distribution with mean 0 and variance \(\frac{1}{n}\)
